text: ANDREW MARSH lies on his back in bed.  He is a frail-look man in his early sixties, with thinning gray hair.  On to him is a much younger WOMAN.  Although her back is to us, catch flashes of her face for a moment as she turns from to side.  We see enough to know that this is a beautiful She moves wildly, grinding her hips into him, her head ar back, her hands rubbing lightly over her breasts.  She re down, grabbing his hips and jerks them upwards, forcing h deeper inside her.  They move together -- faster -- and f The CAMERA slowly begins to PULL BACK.  As it does we see we are watching is on a TELEVISION. Further back still.  We see TWO UNIFORMED POLICE OFFICERS standing before the television watching the act. The CAMERA begins to pan around the room.  Rain streaks d the windows of the room -- LIGHTNING flashes outside.  A CAMERA is set up on a tripod.  More PLAIN CLOTHES POLICE, looking, dusting, talking. We continue to PAN.  We can now see it is the same room o tape.  ON the bed lies the naked body of ANDREW MARSH, a covering his lower torso.  His face is ashen, mouth open, dull eyes looking out in a fixed stare.  The last instant his life is etched upon a face frozen in pain.

LIGHTNING fills the night sky.  THUNDER BOOMS overhead. wind whips the RAIN furiously against anything in its pat The CAMERA moves slowly along rows of beautiful HOMES.  A end is a cul-de-sac.  Several POLICE CARS are in the driv their RED LIGHTS FLASHING. A four-door SEDAN pulls into the driveway.  JOHN CARDENAS out into the rain.  He is a handsome Latin in his thirtie with hard, chiseled features and black, slicked-backed ha He does not run through the rain -- he walks. DETECTIVE REESE, a man who looks more like an accountant homicide detective runs out to meet him.
Is it Marsh?
Yeah. Just a hint of sadness shows on Cardenas' face.  It lasts instant, then it's gone.
Sir, do you mind if we get out of the rain? Cardenas doesn't move.  He ignores the question.
Who found him?
His Secretary.  Joanne Braslow.
She was here?
No.  She stopped by to pick up some papers.
Show me. Reese starts for the house.  Cardenas looks up into the n sky.  A FLASH of LIGHTNING fills the SCREEN.

Pull back to reveal a POLICE PHOTOGRAPHER snapping pictur Marsh in bed. Cardenas enters followed by Reese.  He moves through the FORENSIC and MEDICAL TEAMS.  Anything Cardenas feels abou gruesome sight before him is hidden behind a mask of indifference. Standing by the bed is ASSISTANT DISTRICT ATTORNEY, ROGER TROXELL, a short, baby-faced man.  Cardenas looks down at body, then over at the MEDICAL EXAMINER, DR. HENRY McCURD portly man with windblown cheeks and bloodshot eyes.
How long?
About three hours.
Cause?
Not sure.  I'll have everything you need tomorrow.

Take a look at this. Reese points to the nightstand drawer and Troxell opens i top of the nightstand is a box of tissues and a bottle of spray.  Inside are ROPES, HANDCUFFS and an assortment of AIDES.
This guy was into some kinky shit. Cardenas looks at the various sexual devices, then walks the room.

JOANNE BRASLOW sits on chair.  Her eyes are tired -- red crying.  She is mid thirties -- attractive, but her looks more from effort than nature -- expensive hair cut -- the cosmetics.  She has a corporate look to her. Cardenas steps into the hall and walks over to her.
Miss Braslow -- I'm District Attorney John Cardenas.  You arrived at what time tonight?
A little after eleven.
Why did you come by?
I had some papers to pick up.
Do you know who Mr. Marsh was with?
I assume his girlfriend.
Her name?
Rebecca Lawson.
You wouldn't know her address, would you?
No -- but I can get it for you.
Thank you.
Cardenas walks down the corridor with McCurdy.
Marsh wasn't alone.  We found traces of sperm on the sheets.  The toxicology report says there were high levels of cocaine in his blood.
What'd he die of?
The official cause of death was a cardiac arrest.
The official cause?
That's what my report will read.
But there's more?
They reach a door and stop.
It's speculative at this point. Marsh had advanced Arterial disease. His heart attack was induced by excessive aerobic activity -- in conjunction with the drug.
McCurdy enters the room.  Cardenas thinks for a moment, t follows.

Spacious and sparsely furnished.  The walls are empty.  N commendations, plaques or photographs to add prestige to office.  Cardenas steps into the room and looks at McCurd is already seated next to Reese and Troxell.
(to McCurdy) What are you saying, Henry?  That his girlfriend fucked him to death?
Yes.
A trace of a grin shows on Cardenas' face.  He walks over the window and stares outside.  Reese, Troxell and McCurd as he thinks.  A beat.  Cardenas turns back to the room.
What can we prove?

We know Marsh had a head cold.   We found cocaine mixed with water in a nasal spray container on the nightstand.  The coke would contract the nasal membrane the same as any decongestant, but for a much shorter time.  He'd keep using more and more -- never knowing what he was taking.
Any prints on the nasal spray?
Marsh's and Rebecca Lawson's.
What if he did know what was in it? A lot of users put it in nasal spray bottles so they can use it in public.
Cocaine is the last thing a man in his condition would want.
Can we put Rebecca Lawson at the scene?
A man across the street from Marsh saw her drive up about four thirty Sunday afternoon.  And her prints are all over the place.
Cardenas stands and walks to a DART BOARD on the wall.  H gathers the DARTS, moves back and tosses one.

Marsh's Cardiologist told me that after Marsh was diagnosed with heart disease he quit smoking, quit drinking and started exercising every day.  Does that sound like a guy who'd start shoveling cocaine up his nose?
What did he say about Miss Lawson?
He can remember at least one occasion -- and the receptionist can recall two times when she accompanied Marsh to the office.
Cardenas throws another dart at the board.
So she knew about his heart?
Had to.  I also interviewed three women who were in past relationships with Marsh.  There's no evidence that he had anything but straight sex prior to meeting Miss Lawson.
What about the will?
That's the best part.  She gets it all -- everything.

Gray clouds hang over head.  A light drizzle falls.  A GR MOURNERS hold umbrellas as they stand around the grave. In the b.g. the PRESS is visible, held back my private SE GUARDS. A WOMAN dressed in BLACK stands in the front of the MOUNE her face hidden behind a hat and veil.  RAYMOND SATTLER, tall, distinguished-looking man in his sixties stands bes her.  He supports his weight with the aid of a CANE.  The service concludes.  Sattler along with several other PEOP offer her their condolences.  Joanne Braslow is there.  S does not go over to Rebecca. CARDENAS AND REESE stand off to the side by a large oak t Cardenas watches and waits.  He steps forward as Sattler the woman by.
Miss Lawson?
The Woman stops.  Her back is to Cardenas.
I'm District Attorney, John Cardenas.

REBECCA LAWSON removes her hat and veil and slowly turns around.  She is in her late twenties.  A deep pain fills face -- controlled, but evident.  Her eyes are tired -- h from crying -- but no tears show now.  This is a woman wh grief is private and not displayed for others.  Although emotionally drained she is still stunningly beautiful.  S beautiful that even Cardenas' usually cool demeanor canno how impressed he is.
I don't think that this is the time, or the place.
I just wanted to introduce myself and inform Miss Lawson that there will be an inquiry.
An inquiry into what?
For starters I'd like to know why she left the house and didn't report the death?
Because he wasn't dead when she left, and even if he was, not reporting a natural death in a timely fashion isn't a crime.
Did I say it was a natural death?
Cardenas and Rebecca lock eyes.  Rebecca stares at him genuinely shocked by his accusation.  Cardenas nods and w away.  In the b.g. we see Joanne staring at Rebecca with hostility.

Large and homey.  A fire roars in the fireplace.  FRANK D sits on his couch as he goes over some PAPERWORK.  He is thirties, powerful, self-assured. SHARON DULANEY enters.  She is an attractive woman in her thirties.  She kisses him on the cheek then pushes his PAPERWORK aside and sits down on his lap.
You're on vacation, remember?  You're supposed to be relaxing.
I am relaxing.
(pushing the papers aside) This is not relaxing.
(playfully) Really?
Really.
(playing along) And I suppose you're going to show me how to relax?
If you want me to.
I'm always open to learning new things.
She kisses him -- soft, gentle kisses.  Dulaney puts his around her and kisses her harder.
I'm beginning to see what you mean. Why don't we go upstairs and work on the advanced course?
I can't.  I've got to finish a counter offer on the Bergman property.
The moment is passing by.  A trace of frustration shows o Dulaney's face -- this is obviously not a new occurrence.
Can't it wait?
No -- it has to be done by tomorrow.
The moment is gone.  Dulaney forces an understanding smil looks towards the door and sees his EIGHT YEAR OLD SON, MICHAEL.
Hey, Slugger.  Ready for bed?
Michael walks over to this parents.
Uh huh.
The PHONE RINGS.  Dulaney answers it.

(into phone) Hello?... Hi Raymond.... What?... Well, I was sort of planning on... Alright... Okay, goodbye. (hangs up; to Sharon) That was Sattler.  He thinks the D.A.'s going to file on Rebecca Lawson.  He wants me in the office tomorrow morning.
We're supposed to go to the lake.
I know.  What can I do?  He is the boss.
He could let you have your vacation.
Dad -- is it true what they're saying about that Miss Lawson Lady?
What are they saying?
The kids at school say she humped Mr. Marsh to death.
Hey, you know better than that.  What did I teach you to say when someone is accused of doing something?
She allegedly humped him to death?
Dulaney grins.  Sharon is fighting the temptation to laug
I swear -- the both of you. (to Dulaney) Some example you set.
(imitating her) Some example you set.

He makes a funny face at Michael who LAUGHS and makes one Dulaney grabs him and starts TICKLING him.  Michael SCREA with LAUGHTER as he tries to tickle him back.  Dulaney th starts TICKLING SHARON -- Michael helps him.  Sharon ROAR LAUGHTER and falls to the floor.  The three of them roll LAUGHING hysterically.
Sattler sits on a couch sipping a cup of coffee.  Dulaney across from him.
Andrew Marsh was a very wealthy man. A trial like this is going to put Cardenas in the spot-light.
We've already got press arriving from over the country and she hasn't even been charged yet. Cardenas wants to see her in his office tomorrow at ten.  I'd like you to go with her.
I'm supposed to be on vacation.
I know -- but she wants you to represent her if Cardenas files.
Why?
Because I told her you were the best criminal attorney we have.
Raymond, I'm the only criminal attorney you have.

(jokingly) Well, I guess that makes you the best. (candidly) Look, Frank -- she stands to inherit three million dollars.  As executors of the estate and her attorneys that could generate a lot of legal fees for us.  All I'm asking you to do is talk to her.
Dulaney thinks about it for a moment.
Alright, I'll talk to her
She's waiting in the conference room.
Dulaney stands and walks towards the door.
(continuing) You know, I knew Andrew Marsh for almost twenty years -- or thought I did.  What do you think would make a man in his condition do the things he did?
Dulaney stops at the door and looks back.
I think the question is:  What is it about her that made him want to do it?

Rebecca is seated at the end of the conference table smok CIGARETTE.  Sunlight flows through a window and highlight hair.  She is dressed in a fashionable business suit that clings to every curve of her body. Dulaney enters the room.  When he sees her he can't help stare.  Rebecca notes his gaze.
Miss Lawson, I'm Frank Dulaney.
She raises the cigarette to her lips.  Dulaney notices de her outward composure her hand is shaking.
(nervously) Are you going to represent me?
There are no charges against you. I'm here to decide if I'm going to represent you should that occur. (beat) Did you kill him?
Rebecca appears hurt by the question.
You don't waste any time, do you?
Dulaney doesn't answer.  He studies her -- his eyes probi hers.
(continuing) Do you think I did it?
I don't know.  That's why I'm asking you.

You must have some feeling.  Some immediate impression.  A young, attractive woman, involved with an older man who leaves her everything in his will.  And the things that went on in that house.  Such wild sex.  What kind of picture does that paint?
Not a very good one I'm afraid.
And that's exactly what the jury will see when they look at me.  That's why I need a very good lawyer, Mr. Dulaney.
You're assuming the District Attorney is going to file charges.
Rebecca's anxiety begins to surface.  She feigns a weak s
He'll file.  He's an ambitious man. Ambitious men build their careers on the bodies of others.
You still haven't answered my question.
She takes a long drag of her cigarette before answering. looks at Dulaney.  Displaying emotions is not something t comes easily.  Tears well up in her eyes.

(emotionally) I loved him.  A big part of my life has been torn away from me, Mr. Dulaney.  A part I can never get back -- and on top of that people are saying that I am somehow responsible for it.  They've taken everything that is good and caring about two people in love and made it dirty.
A single tear streams down her check.  She knows what he to hear her say -- and she resents having to say it.
No -- I didn't kill him.
Cardenas walks down the hall, sipping a cup of coffee.  T walks towards him excitedly.  They walk together.
I think I'm going to make your day.
How?
Troxell points to an Office.  Through the glass partition can see a MAN sitting at a table.  ALAN PALEY is a well-g man in his thirties who makes every effort to look good.
I've got this guy in my office. Doctor Alan Paley.  Wait until you hear what he has to say.
Cardenas and Troxell enters the room.  Cardenas shakes ha with Paley and listens with great interest as he starts t talk.
Dulaney and Sharon are in bed.  Dulaney reads some PAPERS Sharon finishes reading her MAGAZINE.  She puts it on the nightstand and looks at Dulaney.
How can Cardenas possibly think he can build a case against two consenting adults?
He must have something or he wouldn't be pressing so hard.
If he files are you going to take the case?
I don't know yet.  I want to hear what she says at her statement tomorrow.
What's she like?
Attractive.  Bright.  Distant. Charming when she wants to be.
Dulaney's description seems to bother her.
She sounds like quite a woman.
(joking) Yeah -- but can she cook?
Sharon hits him on the arm playfully.
The whole thing gives me the creeps. I mean -- what if she really humped him to death?
Dulaney grins at her choice of words.
Humped
(grinning) Yes.
I can think of worse ways to go--
Dulaney rolls over, gathering her up in his arms.
(continuing) --and speaking of humping.
He reaches over to the nightstand and turns off the LIGHT
As Dulaney and Rebecca walks up the steps they are engulf a CROWD of REPORTERS.  Dulaney puts his arm around Rebecc ushers her through the crowd.
Dulaney and Rebecca sit on one side of a table.  Reese st Cardenas sits at his desk.
I didn't know that Andrew was dead until Mr. Sattler called me at home that night.
We have a witness who saw you go into the house at four thirty.
She's not denying she was there.
Did you have sex?
Yes.
What time did you leave?
Six thirty -- and he was very much alive.
Miss Lawson, do you use cocaine?
I have.
Did you use it the night Marsh died?
No.  I haven't done it in years.
Did Marsh use it?
No -- never.
It had to get there somehow.
It didn't get there from me.
Were you aware of Mr. Marsh's heart condition?
No.
Mr. Marsh's Cardiologist and his nurse have told us that you accompanied Mr. Marsh to their office on at least two occasions.
That's correct -- but Andrew never told me he had a heart condition.  He said he had a heart arrhythmia and it was nothing serious.
He never mentioned his heart disease?
She just said that.
Why do you think he lied to you?
That's something only Marsh would know.
I think Miss Lawson knew it too.  I think she slipped him the coke and he popped his cork giving her the high- hard-one.
Dulaney's anger shows.  He stands.
That's it.  My client doesn't have to take this crap from you.
Sit down, Frank.
No.  Miss Lawson came in here voluntarily to answer your questions. She doesn't have to sit here and be insulted.  So, either you charge her now or we're leaving.
A beat.  Dulaney and Cardenas lock eyes.  Cardenas shrugs shoulders.
Fine.
Dulaney motions for Rebecca to get up.  She stands and th walk to the door.  Reese looks at Cardenas.  Cardenas nod
Rebecca Lawson, you're under arrest for the murder of Andrew Marsh.
Rebecca is stunned -- frightened.  She looks at Dulaney i disbelief.  Dulaney looks at Cardenas angrily.  Reese rem his handcuffs as he moves towards Rebecca.
You have the right to remain silent. If you give up--
(to Reese) I don't think the handcuffs will be necessary.  You can finish giving Miss Lawson her rights outside.
Reese grabs Rebecca by the arm and leads her to the door. looks back at Frank, her face filled with fear -- her eye welling with tears.
(frightened) Frank!
I'll have you out in a few hours.
Reese ushers her through the door.  A beat.  Dulaney and Cardenas are left alone.  Cardenas starts fishing through of NUTS, carefully extracting the cashews.  Dulaney conti to stand.
Lookin' to make the papers, John?
Marsh left her close to three million dollars in his will.  That's motive. She admits to being there the night of his death.  That's opportunity -- and her fingerprints are on the nasal spray bottle.
(continuing) You can't show intent.
Cardenas looks at Dulaney wryly.  He knows that Dulaney i trying to discover his game plan.  Cardenas looks into hi of nuts and fishes for another cashew.
(continuing) Can you?
Take your pole out of the water, Frank.  The fish ain't biting today.
You're bluffing.  John, it's me, remember?  I've known you since your name was Juan Carlos.
Cardenas doesn't appreciate Dulaney mentioning his real n
(continuing) C'mon -- think about it.  If she was going to kill Marsh why leave the nasal spray bottle there for the police to find?
She planned this.  She wanted us to find the nasal spray.
Why would she want that?
Because she's clever.  Because she knows that even if we didn't find it we'd have suspicions as to why a man in Marsh's condition would use cocaine.
Suspicions maybe -- but suspicions aren't enough for a conviction.

The M.E.'s report stated that Marsh's nasal membranes showed no sign of prior cocaine use.  Without the nasal spray we would have still treated it as a poisoning.  We would have looked for motive and the trail would have still led back to her.
I don't buy it and neither will a jury.
We're going all the way on this one, Frank.  Tell your client she has until the prelim to cop a plea for murder two -- fifteen to twenty five.
I'll tell her but she won't take it.
Then she's not as smart as I thought she was.  You've seen her in the depositions.  Tell me you don't have any doubts?
She's innocent.
Aren't they all?
Yeah.  Well -- we'll let the blindfolded lady with the scales decide that.
Dulaney gets up slowly and leaves.
Dulaney waits at the counter.  A barred door slides open Rebecca is led out by a WOMAN JAILER.  Even in these surroundings she maintains her composure.  She walks to t counter and waits silently.
As Dulaney and Rebecca leave they are once again encircle REPORTERS, screaming questions, asking them to verify Reb arrest.  Dulaney plows through the crowd with Rebecca in
Gray clouds hang overhead, threatening rain.  Tall birch line the river, the color of their leaves hinting that au is approaching.  Dulaney and Rebecca walk along a jogging cut along the bank.
I want you to know right now that the trial's going to be nasty.  Your sex life is going to be dragged through the mud.  They're going to say that you enticed Marsh -- led him down a dark path.
Andrew hardly needed leading.  He was a very passionate man.  He was eager to explore.  I gave him what he wanted.  We fulfilled each others needs.
This is a very small town -- people here have very straight views on sex.

I'm used to being on the outside looking in.  The same men who will publicly profess their moral outrage for my sexual tastes are the same ones who privately rest their sweaty little hands on my legs and talk about weekend trips together.
Those same men will be sitting on the jury.

I am who I am.  I can't deny it, anymore than you can deny who you are.  I like sex different -- I like it wild.  That's not a crime. (emotional) I loved Andrew.  We made love together.  We made it differently, but we still made love.  It was our way.  It was private -- and now the whole world wants to look in through the pretense of justice.  If I was some middle-aged divorcee who screwed him once a week do you think this would be happening to me?
She stops walking and stares out over the River.
Have you ever seen animals make love, Mr. Dulaney?  They have such passion -- such savage emotion.  They struggle, and snarl, and claw, but neither hurts the other.  Not really.
No pain, no gain?
Something like that.
We're not animals.
As Rebecca speaks, Dulaney seems captivated.

Of course we are.  Our primal urges are still there -- but we've taken sex and intellectualized it, refined it down to its most essential components.  It's bland, easy, mechanical.  There's great passion in the struggle -- such craving in denial.  Do you know what it's like to yearn for something?  I'm not talking about wanting, or needing. I'm talking about an urge so deep that your skin burns and every cell in your body pulses with desire?
Dulaney appears moved by the passion of her words -- but uncomfortable by it and quickly pushes it aside.
(awkwardly) I think we're getting a little off the subject here.
I thought the subject was sex?
As it pertains to you -- not me. (beat) Did you always know you had different... tastes?
Yes.
How?
I don't know if it's something I can explain to you.
Why not?
Because -- it's beyond intellect. It's emotion.  It's passion.  It has to be experienced -- it can't be imagined.
Try.
Rebecca thinks for a moment.

When I was growing up we had a strawberry patch in our backyard. So did this family down the road.  I used to sneak in their yard and steal their strawberries.  It wasn't easy. The stone walls were high and I'd scrape my knees as I climbed over. On the other side were wild rose bushes.  The thorns would dig into my legs and cut my thighs as I lowered myself down.
If you had what you wanted at home why did you sneak into their yard?
Because -- somehow the fruit always tasted that much sweeter because of the pain it took to get to it.
Dulaney appears lost in her words.  This isn't lost on Re She walks off.  Dulaney stares after her intrigued.
A light rain falls outside.  Dulaney picks at his food. stares out the window.  He seems oblivious to the convers between Sharon and Michael.
Albert's got the stomach flu.
That's too bad.
No, it's not.  Now I get to pitch.
Michael, you shouldn't be happy when someone else isn't feeling well.
Not even if they're a dork?
Not even if they're a dork.  You should go by and see how he's feeling.
No way.  Jerry Milner stopped by and Albert puked right in front of him.
Sharon tries to suppress a grin.
Don't use language like that at the dinner table.
Sorry.
Sharon looks at Dulaney.  He is still staring out the win deep in thought.
Dulaney is at his desk, looking at PHOTOGRAPHS of Marsh a bedroom.  Sharon enters.
Frank -- I know you're busy, but Michael asked me after dinner if you were angry with him.  He wanted to know why you weren't talking to him.
I'll talk to him later.
Why don't you talk to him now?
Because I go to trial in seven weeks. I've got a lot of preparing to do.
(angry) No one's asking you not to work.  I just think you could make some time for your son.
Michael lies on his bed, doing his homework.  The door op and Dulaney enters and sits beside him.
I'm sorry if it looks like I'm not paying attention to you lately.
Michael looks at Dulaney somewhat confused.  Dulaney trie explain it another way.

(continuing) You know how it is sometimes when you're out playing ball with your friends?  How you're really concentrating on what you're doing -- and you lose track of time and you come home late and Mom yells at you?
Yeah.
Well, that's kind of how I am right now.
Is Mom yelling at you too?
Dulaney grins.
Yeah -- a little.
Dulaney leans over and hugs Michael.
I love you.
I love you too, Dad.
CHARLIE BIGGS is a tall, wiry black man.  Street-wise, bu basically good humored.  He is tossing a NERF BALL throug basketball hoop mounted on the wall as Dulaney enters.
How you doin' Mister D?
Fine, Charlie.  You familiar with the Marsh case?

Yeah -- I hear they had 'em a real dog and pony show going on up there - -  I'll tell you, sometimes white people are a real puzzle to me.  I mean, did this old guy really think he was gonna be able to keep up with a sweet little number like that?
It could've happened to anyone.
(ghetto accent) I'm sorry, man -- but I ain't ever heard of no brother dying from gettin' too much pussy.
Dulaney grins in spite of himself.
We have to find out who else would profit from Marsh's death -- and who knew enough about his personal life to know that putting cocaine in the nasal spray would be fatal.
So -- where do we start?
I want you to hit all the dealers in town.  Give them a list of people close to Marsh and see if any of them use.  Then I want you to check out a Doctor Alan Paley.  He lives up in Roseburg.
Dulaney's SECRETARY'S VOICE crackles over the intercom.
Mister Dulaney, I have Rebecca Lawson on one.
Dulaney picks up the phone.
(on the phone) Hi... No, I don't... One o'clock is fine... Alright La Brasa... Bye.
Dulaney hangs up.  Biggs is staring at him with a grin.
La Brasa?
(defensive) I'm taking a client to lunch.  Where should I go, Taco Bell?
Biggs tosses the ball to Dulaney, then raises his hands indicating he is backing off.  He leaves.  Dulaney shoots his desk.  SWOOSH!

Dimly lit.  Dark wood and leather.  Dulaney sits at a tab with Rebecca.  She removes a CIGARETTE and holds it, wait for Dulaney to light it.  Dulaney fumbles through his poc and removes a book of MATCHES.  He lights one.  Rebecca d lean forward to meet him.  He must go to her.  She looks his eyes as she cups her hand over his.  A beat.  She lig the cigarette and takes a drag, then arches her neck back blows a stream of smoke towards the ceiling.  SHE DOES NO OUT THE MATCH OR REMOVE HER HAND FROM DULANEY'S.  She wat him as it burns down towards his fingers.  After a long m she leans in and sensually blows out the match and releas hand.
How'd you meet Marsh?
I was at a cocktail party.  Very trendy.  Andrew was in Chicago on business.  He had broken his wrist the week before and was wearing it in a sling.  He looked so helpless.
A FOURSOME a few tables away are staring at her.  Rebecca them.
-- And then?

We started talking.  In fact, we talked until four in the morning.  We discovered we shared a lot of the same interests.  After that we were together all the time until he left. He used to call me every night after he came back.  Then after a few weeks he invited me to come visit him. I've never left.
Why didn't you live together?
Andrew was worried about how it would look.
A COUPLE in a booth are looking at Rebecca and whispering Rebecca and Dulaney notice them.
Can we get out of here?
Sure.  Where to?
Rebecca stands up.  She doesn't answer.  She just walks o
Dulaney pulls up in his car behind Rebecca's.  They get o Dulaney follows her as she walks to the door.
This is your house.
(walking towards the door) I know.
Dulaney stops.
I don't think this is a good idea.
Rebecca stops and turns towards him.
Why not?
Because, I'm your attorney.  I shouldn't be going to your house.
Is it against the law?
No -- it just doesn't look right.
Rebecca stares at him for a moment, then looks down the s to her left and back to her right, then back at Dulaney.
No one's looking.
She walks to her front door and opens it.  She enters, le the door open.  Dulaney waits for a moment, then follows.

Dulaney enters.  Rebecca is standing in the middle of the Her back is to Dulaney, but she knows he is there.  Dulan looks around the room.  He stares at a group of PHOTOGRAP the wall.  On the other WALL is a GIANT TELEVISION SCREEN
filled with EROTIC PAINTINGS AND PHOTOGRAPHS -- sensual b vulgar. Rebecca walks over and stands very close to him as he stu the artwork.
What do you think?
I think the photographer's probably a voyeur.
I'm the photographer.
Oh -- Well, they're different.
That's not an answer.
It's not my taste.
(seductively) Tastes can change.
